Introduction

In operating this policy it is the intention of the Trust to comply with the Health and Safety at Work. Etc Act, The Management of Health & Safety at Work Regulations and the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations (as amended) to ensure adequate resources and procedures are in place to reduce the risk, so far as is reasonably practicable, to staff and patients arising from their sensitivity to natural rubber latex (NRL).

Latex is used in the manufacture of many of medical products commonly used in the healthcare setting, such as gloves, catheters, tubing, tourniquets, bandages anaesthetic and resuscitation equipment. Allergy to Latex protein has emerged as a significant health problem to hospital staff and patients since the early 1980s.

Latex is recoginsed as a “sensitiser” and a substance “hazardous to health” as defined  by  the  Control  of  Substances  Hazardous  to  Health  (2002)  (COSHH) regulations. Associated health problems include immediate Type 1 Latex allergy and allergic contact dermatitis.
Scope
This policy applies to to all employees of the Trust, including all volunteers and staff employed on temporary or honorary contracts.
The purpose of this policy is to:
Assess  the  risks  and  where  practically  possible  eliminate  the  use  of  NRL products from the service or control / reduce the exposure of staff to NRL
Ensure only Latex free gloves are utilised for general examination purposes
Limit latex usage to essential use only e.g. if required a measure of precision and dexterity. Once a need is established, ensure risk assessment and annual health surveillance is undertaken

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Health and Safety Committee is responsible for monitoring implementation of this policy and to receive and review instances of Latex allergy.
Chief Executive

Has  overall  has  overall  responsibility  to  provide  a  safe  working  environment, ensuring compliance with the requirements of all health and safety legislation, and also has overall responsibility for the safety of any patients, visitors or contractors whilst they are on Trust premises.
Chief Nurse
Has delegated responsibility at Executive Board level for risk management and is responsible for ensuring:
There are sufficient resources for the implementation of this Policy.
That this policy is appropriately disseminated throughout the Trust.
The use and management of latex throughout the Trust is both systematic and appropriate.
Directors and Senior Managers
Have a responsible for managing the risk management process by:
Ensuring suitable and sufficient risk assessments such as those associated with NRL are carried out in the workplace.
Appropriate control measures are implemented.
Resources are allocated for such equipment as is necessary and reasonably practicable to avoid hazardous processes or exposure to known hazards.
Staff  identified  as  being  service  leads  are  given  sufficient  information, supervision, instruction and training.
Trust Managers
Are responsible for:
Ensuring that as part of the risk assessment process, managers must only procure products, via the Trust procurement systems and where possible utilise latex free products only.
Ensure staff have awareness of the hazards presented by products made from NRL.

That whenever latex products and materials are identified, and where reasonably practicable, replaced with non-latex alternatives. Where this is not achievable, assessment for uage and safe systems of work should be developed to minimise exposure. To aid in departmental assessment of latex risk management the appropriate latex questionnaire / form can be utilised to record actions (refer to appendices 1,2 & 3).
Ensuring that the risk associated with NRL allergy to patients and HCW's are managed in accordance with this policy and associated guidance and procedures.
Ensuring that this policy is brought to the attention of all staff within their areas.
Ensuring that NRL Risk Assessments are undertaken with regard to the use of low protein latex powder free gloves for work and clinical activities.

Ensuring HCWs are provided with appropriate information instruction and training to enable them to manage NRL allergy including the need to report allergic reactions to NRL or symptoms suggestive of NRL allergy.
Ensuring any NRL allergic reactions are reported to the Trust via associated incident reporting system and process.
Referring any HCW with symptoms suggestive of a latex allergy to the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service.
Identifying all staff members who are exposed to Latex and ensuring they complete an annual Latex health surveillance questionnaire.
Procurement Department
Responsible for ensuring:
That where reasonably possible, equipment, materials and substances purchased for Trust use are latex free.
That a record of all products which do or do not contain latex within the Trust is maintained.
That all latex gloves purchased are low protein and non-powdered.

When products containing significant amounts of latex are identified that further information is obtained from suppliers, manufacturers, clinicians or the person requiring the product to ascertain its suitability for use in the Trust.
Review and monitoring of glove purchasing and usage.
Ensuring that as part of the risk assessment process, managers  must only procure products, via the Trust procurement systems and where possible utilise latex free products only.
Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service
Responsible for :
Providing confidential health advice to individual staff members experiencing adverse health effects due to latex including advice on prevention and minimisation of symptoms.
Reviewing immunisation and infection screening questionnaires at the preappointment health screening stage to identify staff at risk of latex allergy or with pre-existing symptoms.
Assessing new staff at risk of latex allergy or with known latex allergy within the first month of employment.
Accepting referrals (from management) of employees with suspected latex allergy.
Providing enhanced health surveillance by means of a questionnaire and feeding back to management on individuals fitness status in relation to staff known to be allergic to latex.

Providing managers with a health surveillance tool to be performed annually on staff who use latex gloves and who are not already under enhanced surveillance by the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service.
Investigating symptoms of staff identified by health surveillance performed locally and advising accordingly if suspected/known latex allergy.
Maintaining a database of known latex allergic staff members and recalling them for health surveillance annually by questionnaire and advising managers accordingly on their fitness status.
Referring staff with suspicious symptoms of latex allergy on to specialist clinics to establish an accurate diagnosis.
Advising procurement on individual staff members glove requirements if specific alternative gloves are required due to allergy.
Providing advice on control measures to reduce the risk of latex allergy.
Infection Control Team
Responsible for:
Providing advice and guidance on the use of gloves for clinical, surgical, cleaning & waste management and the barrier performance of these gloves.
Encourage services to modify their practices to ensure safe use of latex products where appropriate.
Ensure that infection prevention guidelines for glove usage are followed.
Assisting in the risk assessment process for glove use in the Trust.
Health and Safety Department
Responsible for:
Ensuring that the DATIX incident reporting stystem is monitored for dermatitis, latex and COSHH related incidents.
Ensuring that RIDDOR cases (related to dermatitis and latex) are reported to the Health and Safety Executive.
Ensuring that reports are provided to the Health and Safety Committee.
All staff
Responsible for:
Adhering to the latex policy to protect themselves and patients from risks associated with exposure to latex.
Being aware of the signs, symptoms and management of latex allergy.
Knowing what equipment / products contain latex and what latex-free alternatives are available.
Knowing where to source latex-alternative products and in the case that no alternatives are available; knowing what steps to take to minimise contact / exposure to latex.

Complying with the Trust's health surveillance programmed by completing questionnaires and returning them to their manager or occupational health promptly. Attend Occupational Health and Wellbeing Department as requested.
Report symptoms / problems associated with the use of latex to their line manager promptly.
Report severe allergic reactions to patients from latex gloves / equipment via DATIX incident form.
Other considerations:
Blood transfusion Service: Where prescribed, the service must supply blood products in Latex free blood bags.

Vascular Access Team: have sourced products with minimal latex regarding provision of treatments where canula's are utilised. (eg The Bionector is manufactured in such a way as to destroy latex proteins (therefore preventing type I reactions), in addition this product does not contain the processing agents associated with delayed hypersensitivity).

Medical Devices: Those responsible for purchasing or acquiring medical devices for Trust purposes must consider that they may contain latex components and parts. If there is evidence of a medical device causing an allergic reaction (because of a latex component) an incident report must be completed and the MHRA may also need to be informed.

Pharmacy: The Pharmacy manager and any other person responsible for purchasing and supplying pharmaceuticals must ensure that all drugs, their packaging and containers are free from latex (so far as is reasonably practicable).
Resuscitation Team: The Resuscitation Team must ensure that resuscitation equipment are free from latex.

Floor laying: Floor layers (and operatives in close proximity to the floor laying process) are at risk because some floor screed products contain latex; these compounds are used to level up uneven floors and provide a smooth surface prior to laying decorative floor coverings.

Latex in celebratory items: Trust discourage the ingress of latex celebration items which may contain latex both from patient relatives and staff. Latex balloons present a substantial risk of exposure latex allergen proteins both from direct contact and indirect via the aeorsol of the powder coating. It is for this reason only foil ballons are approved for usage in celebratory events on Trust premises.
Adverse health effects (general information)
There are three types of allergic adverse reactions from exposure to latex. These are Latex Allergy (Type 1, Allergic Contact Dermatitis (Type IV) and Irritant Contact Dermatitis.
Latex Allergy (Type 1 reaction – Immediate hypersensitivity)
Latex allergy is a reaction to the natural proteins found in latex. This type of reaction produces symptoms within 5-30 minutes of latex exposure. A variety of symptoms may occur including:
Local or generalised erythema (redness)
Urticaria (rash)
Angioedema (swelling)
Rhinitis (runny nose)
Conjunctivitis (eye inflammation)
Asthma (breathing difficulties)
Laryngeal oedema (throat swelling)
Hypotension (low blood pressure)
Collapse
The severity of symptoms varies. In rare cases, it can lead to life-threatening respiratory difficulties and anaphylactic shock.

Type 1 latex allergy is diagnosed from the employees or patients history, combined with demonstrating the presence of specific IgE (immunoglobulin E) antibodies to latex, either by ‘skin prick testing' or a blood test for latex specific IgE (RAST).
Allergic Contact Dermatitis (Type IV reaction – delayed hypersensitivity)
Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to the chemicals used in the production of latex, mostly the accelerators. It causes an eczematous rash at the site of contact

with latex, usually on the hands. The reaction requires longer exposure than Type 1 reactions and is delayed in onset, beginning several hours after contact, reaching a maximum after 6 – 48 hours and then subsiding. With repeated exposure to the chemicals in the latex product a persistent rash may occur. Although the severity of the rash can vary, this reaction is usually mild and is not potentially dangerous. Type IV contact dermatitis is diagnosed from the history combined with confirmation by ‘patch testing' showing an allergic response to the chemicals in latex.
Irritant Contact Dermatitis
Staff may also suffer from irritation from exposure to latex, however this is a nonallergic condition, and symptoms usually resolve once contact with latex ceases.

Irritation is usually characterised with a rash which is normally dry and itchy. It is important to note however that skin irritation may be caused by a wide range of substances (e.g. skin cleansing and disinfecting agents) and therefore caution must be taken not to assume straight away it is from exposure to latex. Although not an allergy, it still requires follow-up with the occupational health & wellbeing service.

Irritant contact dermatitis is diagnosed from the history and a trial of treatment of good hand care. Irritant dermatitis is a common cause of hand eczema. If hand eczema is persistent, latex allergy (allergic contact dermatitis) should be excluded by patch testing.
Reducing the risk of exposure to latex
Protective Gloves

Protective gloves are an essential item in healthcare today in order to protect healthcare workers against blood borne viruses and other microorganisms. There are four main types of gloves in use across the Trust, and these are listed below. The  glove  algorithm  at  Appendix   provides  a  simple  way  for  staff  to  identify whether gloves are needed and if so, which glove is the most appropriate to wear.
Latex Gloves

In principle, latex gloves should only be used for sterile tasks e.g. surgery, dressings, and where the patient or member of staff does not have a latex allergy this is because these gloves have excellent elasticity, durability and tactile properties for these types of tasks.

However, if in clinical opinion, there is a clinical need for latex gloves to be used in non-sterile tasks, a risk assessment will need to be completed and sent to the local Occupational Health & Wellbeing service.

The risk assessment will need to detail the reasons why there is a clinical need for non-sterile latex gloves i.e. dexterity and tactility reasons, and the consequences of not having them. Once received the Occupational Health Wellbeing service will discuss the risk assessment with the manager for the department and a decision will be made as to whether non-sterile latex gloves are permitted.

The Trust only purchases low protein, non-powdered latex gloves to reduce the risk of exposure further. Powdered gloves are banned within the Trust as the powder can attach to the proteins in the latex gloves which become airborne when the gloves are removed. Inhaling the powder may lead to respiratory sensitisation. In addition, the powder may be introduced into a patient's body or come into contact with mucosal surfaces.
Nitrile Gloves

Nitrile gloves should be used for all non-sterile tasks that involve prolonged glove use for more than ten minutes, stretching, pulling and twisting of the glove and fine or precise movements e.g. venupuncture, unless a risk assessment indicates the use of latex gloves. Nitrile gloves are also an alternative to latex gloves in sterile tasks where a patient or member of staff has a latex allergy.
Neoprene / Polyisoprene Gloves
These are an alternative to latex gloves in sterile tasks where a patient or member of staff has a latex allergy. They should be used if nitrile gloves do not allow sufficient dexterity.
Vinyl Gloves

These should be used for non-sterile tasks that involve brief glove use, for less than 10 minutes, no stretching, pulling and twisting of the glove and no fine or precise movements e.g. emptying catheter bags.

Staff who are identified as having Type 1 latex allergy will be advised not to use latex gloves, but to use the alternatives available. For members of staff who are diagnosed as having Type IV latex allergy an alternative glove will be provided that does not contain the chemical to which they are allergic. This may require supplying alternative gloves to those listed above (outside of the procurement contract) on a named staff member basis as advised by the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service.
Purchasing of latex products

The Procurement department will attempt to procure latex-free products and devices at the contracting stage where possible. However, they will always be guided by clinical opinion and preference and therefore if a non-latex product is deemed to be unsuitable, they will procure the latex alternative.
Any latex products will be clearly labelled as containing latex and staff will need to undertake appropriate checks prior to using latex products on patients.
Where staff members are allergic to latex, they must avoid using the product and where possible, seek an alternative or take steps to minimise contact / exposure to latex.
Procurement will only purchase non-powdered low-protein latex gloves and will continue to review and monitor glove purchasing (including latex alternatives) and usage.
Purchasing / ingress of latex products – celebration items

Latex in celebratory items to mark staff events – Trust discourage the ingress of latex celbration items which may contain latex for usage at staff events. Latex balloons present a substantial risk of exposure latex allergen proteins both from direct contact and indiect via the aeorsol of the powder coating. It is for this reason only foil ballons are approved for usage in celbratory events which Trust premises.
Reducing the risk of exposure to latex (new staff)

All new employees to the Trust are required to complete an online Pre Placement Questionnaire (PPQ) which is assessed by the Occupatonal Health and Wellbeing Department. Staff who change roles are also required to complete a modified PPQ to indicate if there are new health issues to be assessed. Further information pertaining to health may be required via telephone, email or face to face.

If the questionnaire identifies staff with risk factors for latex (e.g. hand eczema) they will be asked to attend the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service for an assessment as soon as possible. Staff members with a confirmed diagnosis of latex allergy will also be seen during pre-appointment screening.

Staff members are encouraged to report symptoms as they arise. Staff who suspect they may be suffering from symptoms associated with latex, e.g. skin irritation, must inform their manager and may be referred formally by their manager to occupational health.

All staff at risk of latex allergy or with a known latex allergy are assessed by occupational health and advice is given on precautions to be taken to reduce the risk of exposure. Staff with symptoms suspicious of latex allergy should be referred via their General Practitioner (GP) to the appropriate specialist clinic, e.g. dermatology or allergy clinic to establish an accurate diagnosis. In cases of irritation, occupational health will advise on hand care and on the appropriate use of gloves in accordance with the Trust glove algorithm (Refer to appendix 4) and will review staff members as necessary.
Health Surveillance
For staff members with a confirmed diagnosis of latex allergy, occupational health
will perform annual health surveillance. This will be undertaken by means of a
questionnaire issued by the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service to individuals
directly. (Refer to Appendix 2: Occupational Health latex surveillance questionnaire)

Managers will be informed that the staff member is under health surveillance and if the individual remains fit to work or if any additional restrictions are required. All members of staff surveyed by the occupational health department will be advised if any additional restrictions are necessary. Annual health surveillance must also be undertaken on all staff that use latex gloves.
This must be performed by the member of staff's manager and can either be done
as part of their appraisal or as a stand-alone exercise on an annual basis. This will
also be undertaken by means of a questionnaire. (Refer to Appendix 3: Annual Latex health questionnaire).

If any questions indicate symptoms associated with latex (indicated by the shaded boxes of the questionnaire) the staff member should be referred to the Occupational Health and Wellbeing service for further assessment.

Copies of all questionnaires should be sent to the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service so these can be added to their occupational health record. These are required to be kept for at least 40 years as required by COSHH Regulations (2002).
Staff risk assessment for latex

The use of latex gloves at work is the single most important risk factor for latex allergy. This will be the main factor in determining the high risk staff group for careful screening for latex allergy, regular skin checks and initial and on-going health surveillance.

The use of latex gloves will be permitted in particular areas, only for specific groups of staff who carry out clinical procedures (surgical or interventional or invasive procedures) which requires superior tactile sensitivity.

A group risk assessment (Refer to Appendix 1 for a Manager's latex risk assessment template) will be facilitated by a nominated local manager (responsible or, or in control of the group of clinical staff) in consultation with the Health and Safety Department, the Occupational Health & Wellbeing service and the Infection Control Department. The risk assessment will be reviewed and audited annually, or as and when:
An incidence of dermatitis is reported in a specified work area.
If it is assessed that the control measures are adequate.
There are other significant changes in the work activity, work environment or the numbers and skill mix of the specified users.
The completed risk assessment will be kept locally and made available to those staff to which it applies; a copy will be kept by the Health & Safety Department.
A risk assessment of working practice will help to determine the type of glove to be used and should consider:
The nature of the task
Consideration of whether gloves are necessary
The risk of contamination from blood or bodily fluids
Whether latex or non-latex gloves are required for the task
Frequency and duration of the contact with the substance or chemical
Durability of the glove for the activity being undertaken including glove strain or risk of tearing
The need for manual dexterity with the glove on
The extent of protection i.e. hands only, full length to elbow
NB only use Latex where risk assessment indicates that there is no suitable alternative.
The completed risk assessment will be kept locally and made available to those staff to which it applies.
Training requirements
Training in relation to risk assessments can be provided by the Health and Safety Department.
Skin health surveillance is undertaken by qualified occupational health practitioners who have had appropriate training.
Management of staff with a latex allergy / sensitivity

Staff should report any symptoms that may be the result of latex allergy to their managers who will then complete a DATIX Incident Report Form. Managers should then complete the Management of Staff Latex Assessment Record form and refer the employee to Occupational Health and Wellbeing Department who will:
Assess the situation, make recommendations and take appropriate action
Refer the person on to a specialist via the GP if the symptoms suggest latex allergy

(NB. Latex management within departments can be proactively managed by completing the Latex risk assessments (appendix 1), the Trust encourages services to adopt an elimination strategy to factor out the potential risks associated with use of latex products.)

Staff with symptoms of latex allergy should be thoroughly investigated by an allergist or expert dermatologist and the diagnosis must be confirmed so that correct measures can be taken at work. Confirmation of the allergy and interpretation of
the results are essential. These may include peak flow meter monitoring, glove wear, skin prick tests, RAST tests for latex specific IgE and a challenge test in a laboratory setting.
Once the diagnosis has been made, it is important that the whole working environment is reviewed to make sure it is safe for the worker. Managers should review the NRL check list and risk assessment.

Vinyl or nitrile gloves should be considered as alternatives. If sterile gloves are required, where possible latex free gloves should be allocated eg a sterile nitrile/vinyl equivalent, or if only sterile latex gloves are available a hypoallergenic sterile latex glove should be provided.

Staff should be encouraged to keep close liaison with the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service and discuss any problems that might occur. They should be made aware of the effects of latex allergy and the problems of encountering latex at home or elsewhere. The Latex Safe Information Leaflet (appendix 5) can be used to raise awareness among staff. Employees should also be made aware of the cross sensitivity that often results between latex and certain fruits.
N.B The Trust will work (via procurement) towards finding a substitute for Latex gloves in all clinical areas.
Monitoring compliance

The local Occupatioal Health and Wellbeing Service will monitor those reporting with latex allergy and dermatitis. This information will be reported to the Health & Safety Committee on an annual basis or when there are concerns about excessive numbers relating to a product reported.

The local Occupatioal Health and Wellbeing Service will inform all cases of work- related dermatitis including those due to irritant dermatitis to the Health & Safety Department for reporting under the RIDDOR regulations. The Health and Safety Team  will  prepare  an  annual  report  from  the  incident  reporting  system  of  all dermatitis and allergy relating to gloves and substances.

data.text: Appendix 2: Latex surveillance questionnaire for sensitised staff

Annual health surveillance is required under the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) regulations for all staff that use latex products at work. According to our records you have been identified as experiencing health problems associated with latex use. Even if you are avoiding latex it is important we monitor your health regularly to ensure your symptoms remain controlled. This questionnaire is designed to identify on-going symptoms that may be associated with
latex allergy. You may be asked to attend for further assessment.

table_items.text: Have you been diagnosed with Latex allergy by a doctor?
Are you able to avoid Latex in your work?
In the last 12 months have you experienced facial swelling, hives, recurrent blocked or runny nose, eye irritation of difficulty in breathing when working or exposed to Latex?
In the last 12 months have you had any symptoms of asthma? (e.g. persistent cough, wheeze, breathlessness)
In the past 12 months have you had any symptoms od dermatitis / eczema on the hands or forearms?
If the answer is YES to questions 4 or 5 Are your symptoms exacerbated / made worse by work? If unsure state Yes
Have you seen your doctor about allergy symptoms, eczema or asthma symptoms in the last 12 months?
Do you have any concerns about your Latex allergy and how Latex is controlled in your work area?

If you report symptoms your manager should refer you to Occupational Health and you may be asked to attend for further assessment

data.text: Appendix 5: Latex safe information leaflet

Are you are allergic to natural rubber latex (NRL)? Contact with this may cause itching, swelling and wheals at the site of contact, and may also cause swelling of the respiratory tract resulting in sneezing and wheezing, and swelling of the conjunctiva resulting in watering eyes.

At present your allergy may not give you many problems, but if you continue to expose yourself to items made from latex you may gradually become more sensitive, so increasing the risk of a more serious reaction. It is therefore advisable to avoid contact with articles containing natural rubber latex as much as possible.
Once sensitised even a short period of contact with natural rubber latex can trigger an allergic reaction. It is most important to take precautions to avoid contact.
The most important items to avoid are latex gloves. People you should inform:

If you visit a doctor, dentist, have blood taken, are scheduled to have a barium enema, etc., you  must inform the attending personnel of your allergy and insist you are not examined by anyone wearing latex gloves.
Also inform your hairdresser and beauty therapist. It is advisable to carry some vinyl or nitrile (synthetic) rubber gloves with you to offer to these persons.
If you need a surgical operation only latex free equipment should be used in the operating theatre, as allergic reactions are most likely to occur when the mucous membranes are exposed to latex.
The fact that you are allergic to latex has been recorded on your medical notes at this hospital.
Please ensure that your GP, dentist and any other relevant personnel also record this fact clearly.
Some products that contain natural rubber latex:

This list is not exhaustive. Additional product information may be obtained by contacting the Customer Service Department at the product manufacturers. As a general rule it is thin, flexible items that are most likely to cause problems:
Balloons and balloon powder
Tyres
Adhesive plaster (e.g. Elastoplast) and glues
Condoms and diaphragm contraceptives. Latex free condoms are available.
Some stretch textiles – Lycra is latex free
Knicker elastic
Cosmetics
Rubber gloves
Sports equipment
Carpeting
Telephone leads
Extension cords
Rubber shoes and boots
Swimming hats and goggles
Hot water bottles
Some shower curtains
Components of wheelchairs
Door and window insulation
Diving masks and equipment
Suspenders
Latex mattresses and pillows
Rubber steering wheel covers
Bicycle/motorbike handle grips
Rubber bands and erasers
Infant dummies
Many children's toys are made of natural rubber latex
Chair cushions
NB: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC), polyurethane (PU) and ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) can be substituted for products containing latex, e.g. shoes and gloves.
Additional information
It is advisable to wear a Medic-Alert bracelet or locket stating that you are “Allergic to Natural Rubber Latex”.

There appears to be some cross-sensitivity between natural rubber latex and some tropical fruits such as banana, melon, avocado and kiwi fruit as well as potatoes and tomatoes. If necessary, please contact your doctor for further information.
When you are exposed to latex, if your symptoms include wheezing, it may be advisable to carry an adrenaline mini-jet. You should discuss this with your doctor
Visitor / Staff Latex Safe Guidelines
Information for visitors and non clinical staff Mid & South Essex University Hospitals, about a latex-safe environment.

For the safety of our patients, visitors and staff at our hospital and clinics, we provide a latex-safe environment. This means our buildings are free of latex powder. For this reason, latex balloons are not allowed in Mid & South Essex University Hospitals (MSE), and associated premises.
Why no latex balloons?

Latex balloons contain a powder which helps release them from molds when they are manufactured. This powder carries latex proteins, which can cause some people to have a severe allergic reaction. Latex balloons have an extremely high level of latex proteins, especially when compared to other products made with latex rubber.
Gifts to patients at MSE Hospitals to select gift options other than latex balloons. Foil balloons are a good alternative.
Common questions and answers about latex and why is latex safe Q: Why are MSE Hospitals latex safe?

A: The effort to be latex safe helps us provide the highest quality patient care. Being latex safe helps prevent reactions among people who are latex sensitive and the possible development of latex allergy because of continuous exposure to latex products over time. Providing this latex safe environment benefits everyone who enters our buildings.
Q: What are the symptoms of a latex allergic reaction?
A: Reactions can range from mild to life-threatening:
Red and swollen skin, rash, hives or itching,
Itchy, watery eyes, runny nose or sinus irritation,
Coughing or difficulty breathing (wheezing, tightness in chest),
"Anaphylatic shock" - any of the above symptoms plus very low blood pressure and obstructed breathing, leading to heart failure and death if left untreated.
Q: How common is latex allergy?

A: From 1 to 6 percent of the general public and 8 to 17 percent of healthcare workers have a latex allergy. The more often a person is exposed to latex, the greater is his or her chance of developing an allergy. Those at highest risk for latex allergy are:
People born with spina bifida,
People who have had multiple surgeries,
People exposed to latex at work,
People allergic to bananas, avocados, kiwi and chestnuts
Q: What is MSE doing to reduce exposure to latex?
A: At MSE we:
Have extensively cleaned our buildings to remove latex powder,
Use powder-free latex gloves and supplies for latex-allergic patients and employees,
Do not allow latexcelbration balloons in of our facilities, Foil ballons are permitted.
